description: This course is concerned with how and why people behave as consumers. Its goals are to: (1) provide conceptual understanding of consumer behavior, (2) provide experience in the application of buyer behavior concepts to marketing management decisions and social policy decision-making; and (3) to develop analytical capability in using behavioral research.
name: CONSUMER BEHAVIOR

values.comments:
This course is concerned with understanding the psychology of customer relationships. The goal of this class is to understand how the basic concepts and principles of consumer behavior can be used to make decisions in the marketing world. Topics discussed during the semester include customer psychological processes and their impact on marketing.

The majority of students enjoyed this course and found it to be “very interesting.” Many students reported liking the lectures. Most also commented that they enjoyed the guest speakers. Some students mentioned that the course put more emphasis on psychology than on marketing.

Students praised Professor Small, saying that they learned a great deal from her course. A few felt there was a lack of communication regarding the material covered on the midterm and final. Overall, though, students said Professor Small “stimulated student interest” and was “always accessible.”

The grade for the course is broken up into class participation, a final exam, group project, and case preparation write-ups. Students must complete either MKTG621 or MKTG622 before taking this course. This course is open to both Wharton freshmen and upperclassmen.
